dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the last word of the quotation FADES from the screen, fog clears, the caged leopard comes into full focus, and see that it is an actual leopard behind actual bars.  Ove the scene is the wheezy music of the Triumphal March from "Aida," as played on a hand, organ. This is playing in th distance, and we do not see the organ-grinder until later The CAMERA DRAWS BACK to show a young artist sitting befo the cage on a campstool with a drawing portfolio in her h She is presumably sketching the panther, although her dra is not shown, and we do not see the features of the girl' face.  The girl picks up the drawing and holds it off, weighing its values. It evidently does not meet with her approval, for she wads the drawing Into a ball and turns look for a place to throw the waste paper. We see her fac It is heart-shaped, demure, even a little naive.  She is small, young,and very beautiful.  In one hand the wad of waste paper is poised, ready to throw into a container. INSERT     WASTEPAPER BASKET as Irena sees it. It is a rather fancy container in the shape of a tree trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (then continuing in the same tone) "Sometimes whoever seeks abroad may find Thee sitting careless on a granary floor, Thy hair soft lifted...  (ponders, as if trying to remember) Thy hair soft lifted..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping her compact shut) Reminds me.  I have a date with the hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a way to spend a Saturday afternoon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The business girl's holiday

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've minded your mother and eaten more bread crusts. You'd have curly hair now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for lunch.  See you at the office Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts off down the promenade. She walks briskly in o direction, while Oliver turns the other way, ambling towa the leopard cage. Along the promenade a file of Saturday afternoon idlers goes by. Oliver moves up to the cages an pauses at the guard rail before the leopard cage. Near hi sits Irena, busily sketching. Oliver looks at her, but sh does not look up at him. She gets up and moves a few step her eyes intent on the movements of the panther, which is walking about In its cage. Oliver politely steps aside so that she can get a better vantage point.  She does not ev notice him. She frowns at her drawing, wads the paper int ball, and turns to throw it into the container. Oliver st before her, smiling and extending his hand. She looks at a moment, then smiles and drops the wad of paper into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an easy aim, Oliver tosses it neatly into the contai and turns to her with a shrug, as if to say how easy it w But Irena has picked up another drawing upon which she ha worked and is now studying it. The music of the organ-gri grows constantly louder as the scene progresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't believe  this,  and you've probably heard  it a dozen times before...but  I've never known any artists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not an artist, really... not a real artist...just a sketch artist for fashion drawings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has picked up the drawing and is holding it in her ha with its back toward Oliver, who extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena smiles but shakes her head as she tears the drawing about two-thirds of the way through, dropping it face dow upon the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. It's not good. If I let you see it, you might not want to know any artists...ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it would have to be pretty bad to do that. Besides, look... (pointing to a drawing she had dropped, quoting in a mocking tone) "Let no one say, and say it to your shame..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena laughs and starts to pick up the paper, but a gust wind blows it down the promenade. She turns to Oliver and shrugs her shoulders. She starts to fold up her campstool Oliver comes forward to offer his assistance. At the same time the organ-grinder passes between them and the camera playing "Aida" on his hand organ. Oliver asks Irena if he help her, but the music is so loud she cannot hear him. H assists Irena in gathering up her things. He takes the campstool, and Irena carries her artist's portfolio.  The start toward the avenue together. CLOSE SHOT of the torn drawing as a little wind, carrying with it some autumn leaves, picks up the paper again and blows it over and over up the promenade.  The torn half o the drawing falls over into place, so we see what Irena h been drawing. It is a smart fashion sketch of the type se in Vogue or Harper's Bazaar, but the face of the model is blunt mask of a black panther, and the hands protruding f the sleeves are tipped with feline talons.  The CAMERA HO on the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT of Irena and Oliver as they walk down a side str Irena is looking straight ahead of her, amused. Oliver is doing his best to get acquainted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena Dubrovna -- is that a Russian name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...I am from Serbia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  Would you mind spelling it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know how to spell my name? Are you going to write me a letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to write you a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say in this letter... "Dear Miss...Dubrovna," I would say, "will you have tea with me?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena shakes her head with a little smile.  Oliver is undaunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in that case, I'd just have to write you another letter, I'd say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But again, with the same teasing smile, she shakes her head.  She suddenly stops and TURNS to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver starts to give her the campstool he is carrying, S lays a soft, gloved hand on his coat sleeve and smiles charmingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, Mr. Reed, you would like to have tea in my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver looks at her quizzically, realizing that she had m to ask him all the time, that he needn't have tried so ha to wangle a date. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Dubrovna, you make life so simple!

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Irena and Oliver as they enter the building from the street.  It is the ornate, elaborate interior of brownstone mansion converted into an apartment house.  Th walk the few steps of the short hallway to the stairs.  Oliver looks at the enormous staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never cease to marvel at what lies behind a brownstone front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT.  Irena has inserted the key in the lock of her door.  She turns it, but before she opens the door, she l up at Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you looked at me in such a funny way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never had anyone here. You're the first friend I've met in America.  I know lots of people in business...editors, secretaries, other sketch artists...you know. But you might be my first real friend.  That's why I looked at you. (pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena swings the door wide open.  Through the doorway a little bit of the room can be seen.  Prominently displaye is an odd equestrian statuette.  It is the figure of a man in armor, carved out of gray stone.  The man wears a regal chaplet on his head and is mounted on a magnificent horse.  Around the base of the statue is a circle of flames, while the rider holds high above his head a sword upon which is impaled the figure o a writhing cat. Irena takes a step into the room and stan waiting for Oliver to follow her, then turns to look back at him. He has become aware of the perfume in the room. OLIVER (cont'd) Mm.  Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Lalage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lalage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perfume I use.  I like it, perhaps too well.  Maybe I use too much of it, living alone like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I like it all right.  It's hard to describe...not like flowers...it's like something warm and living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes on into the room, she closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of statuette. The figure is silhouetted against a window dim with twilight. As the CAMERA HOLDS o the statuette, a light appears in a bay window across the street, bringing the figures of horse, king, and cat into dramatic focus. Over the shot we hear Irena's voice hummi "Berceuses du Chat" by Stravinsky. The CAMERA PANS to show Irena and Oliver seated together couch near the window. Because of the dim light in the ro they can barely be seen. Oliver is listening to her sing. ends her song, and they sit quietly for a moment. Suddenl as sometimes happens, there is a lull in the traffic outs In this momentary stillness, this stillness in which a gr city seems to catch its breath, Oliver hears the sound of distant roaring, muffled and yet full of savage reverberation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking toward Irena) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the lions in the zoo. One can hear them here often. Many people in this building complain. The roaring keeps them awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't mind it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  To me it's the way the sound of the sea is to others, natural and soothing.  I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks out the window, then turns back to Oliver. IRENA (cont'd) Some nights there is another sound. The panther.  It screams... like a woman.  I don't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver strikes a match to light his cigarette. He looks a Irena's face in the dancing match light.  She smiles at h IRENA (cont'd) I hadn't realized how dark it was getting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises and goes over to a lamp. She speaks in a sighin breath of ecstasy. IRENA (cont'd) I like the dark.  It is friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns on the lamp. Now, in the light, we see her apartment ГўВЂВ” a nicely proportioned living room with a fireplace set under a neat Georgian mantel. Doors at eith end of the room lead off into small bedrooms.   Behind a fantastic three-part screen on which is painted the long, sleek figure of a black leopard against a background of jungle foliage, is concealed the two-burner stove, tiny s and old-fashioned icebox which make up the kitchenette. the other corner, under the wide window, are a drawing bo and a desk, littered with crayons, brushes, bottles of discolored water, and papers.  On one side of the wall, i neat frames, hang three of Grandville's amusing studies o cats dressed as humans. Over the mantel hangs a beautiful reproduction of Goya's sinister portrait of Don Manuel Os do Zunlga and the cats.  In front of Oliver, on the coffe table, are the remnants of their tea.  Irena comes down t pick the tray up to take it into the kitchenette. Oliver starts to help her, but she stops him. IRENA (cont'd) No, no. Sit still, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to dump the ash trays and collect the saucers cups. Oliver smokes contentedly.  Irena carries the tray behind the screen.  Oliver snuffs out the cigarette and p the statue up, holding it for a moment in his hand. IRENA (cont'd) (coming out from behind screen; eagerly) Are you admiring my statue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who does not like it at all) Not exactly. Who's it supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King John?  The Magna Carta and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.  King John of Serbia. He was a fine king. He drove the Mamelukes out of Serbia and freed the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why have this around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you have in your room a picture of George Washington or Abraham Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still unconvinced) Aren't there some better statues of him -- some without that cat thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  There are beautiful statues of King John.  There is one in Belgrade, where his face shines with goodness.  But this statue reminds me of my home, the little village where I was born.  This is the statue that stands in the square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what does it mean? Why is he spearing that cat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena turns, her back to the fireplace mantel.  In her ha is the statue of King John. Above her, to one side, the t cats in the Goya portrait glare from the shadowed backgro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not really a cat.  It's meant to represent the evil ways into which my village once had fallen.  You see, the Mamelukes came to Serbia long, long ago, and they made the people slaves. But my village was too little, too far away in the mountains. They left it alone. For five hundred years my little village was cut off from the Mother Church. At first the people were good and worshipped God in a true Christian way. But, little by little, the people changed.  When King John drove out the Mamelukes and came to our village he found dreadful things. The people bowed down to Satan and said their Masses to him. They had become witches and were evil. King John put some of them to the sword and burned some of them in fires. (pauses, drops her voice a little) But some --the wisest and the most wicked -- escaped into the mountains. (looks at Oliver) ) Now, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver comes over beside her near the mantel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't see what it has to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena looks down at the statue of King John. There is a haunting look of memory in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those who escaped ГўВЂВ” the wicked ones -- their legend haunts the village where I was born.  The past remains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks off suddenly, conscious that she has spoken to much and too frankly. A little ormolu clock on the mantel strikes the hour.  It is six.  It is obvious that Irena welcomes the interruption and she glances down at her own wrist watch.  Oliver takes the hint.  He starts toward th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he picks up his things) Boys who come to tea can't expect to stay to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena has followed Oliver out and stands in the doorway Oliver turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When am I going to see you again? Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena nods with a smile, Oliver continues to the head of stairs and turns back. OLIVER (cont'd) What time tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena shrugs her shoulders. OLIVER (cont'd) Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena nods and smiles at him. SHOT of stairway as Oliver comes down the stairs. He reac a landing, turns, and looks up,  Irena is looking down at from the bannister. They both smile. He continues down th stairs. At the very bottom he looks up again. Irena is st standing watching him. He smiles up at her and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE VIEW. The Consolidated Ship and Barge Construction Company has a handsome drafting office. Severe and modern it is nevertheless a room that immediately suggests shipbuilding. A wide doorway opens in from the hall, in t f.g. are three draftsmen's tables, glass-topped and light from beneath. Behind them are several tables for other workers. There are a number of rows of filing cabinets, a at one side is a water cooler. The back wall of the offic is unadorned, wide, and slightly curving. At the moment, group of office workers are just starting to paste up the sectional plans of a ship, entitled "PROJECT NO. 457," on this wall. The ship's bow can be seen taking form in detailed constructional profile.  Two of the three draftsmen's tables in the f.g. are now occupied. Oliver sits working at one of them. The center one is unoccupied. At the other one, a tall, lean Englishman works. This is James Carver. At the back wall, Alice Moore is supervising two workers, who are doi the actual pasting. She holds in her hands a small sheet paper with the detailed mathematical measurements of the project, Beside her, Commodore Judson, head of the Consolidated Sh and Barge Construction Company, stands watching the begin of the project with genuine delight. He is a bald, bearde gentleman and would look like an amiable tramp rather tha the head of a successful shipbuilding company, if it were for the seamanlike neatness of his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning to one of the men at the wall) A little more to the left, Harry. Easy...just a hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts her hand to indicate that it's in position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By George! This is going to bo our best yet. Wait till she rides into Tokyo Bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got what it takes all right, Commodore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice turns and goes to the desk between Oliver and Jim Carver.  She picks up a sheet of paper from the desk and just about to return to the wall, when she is stopped by the sound of a cat's mewing. She listens. The mew is repeated. Carver raises his head and also listens. Alice takes a look at the floor under and around her desk,  Oliver is still bending over his work, Alice looks suspiciously and questioningly at Carver, Carver replies throwing his hands out to show that he doesn't know,and then pointing to himself and shaking his head to announce that the mew is not coming from him. The mewing continues during this, which is one reason Carver and Alice do not speak. They are listening. Alice and Carver both turn and look at Oliver, He knows very well that they are looking him, and his pose is one of elaborate innocence. There is light cardboard box on his desk. The CAMERA FOCUSES on it as the lid of the box rises, and the head of a very small Siamese kitten pokes out, Alice hurries to Oliver's desk, uttering a cross between a coo and a cry of pleased surprise. ALICE (cont'd) A-a-ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the kitten and cuddles it against her cheek. ALICE (cont'd) It's a darling! Where'd you got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commodore has joined them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to start keeping cats, are you? (scratching kitten's head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Commodore, I just got it for a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We arrive at the inescapable conclusion that our Oliver  (he is addressing the assembled multitude) has a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brilliant deduction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Carver's arm and draws him away/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost as if correcting her)  A girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver takes the kitten and puts it back into the box. It makes vain efforts to scramble out past his restraining hand,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, but I know you'll like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice watches him try to got the cover of the box over th protesting kitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like her, she's okay with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS DOWN to CLOSE SHOT of kitten, and as the lid the box hides It from view, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT.  Oliver, with the boxed kitten under one arm, ringing the bell to Irena's apartment. After a moment, sh opens the door. She is wearing a paint-stained smock and obviously boon interrupted in her work. She smiles at Oli and he bends down to put the box on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Irena.  I brought you a present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the kitten out of the box and sets it on the flo Irena stoops down beside it. Seeing her, the kitten draws back, arching itself. Oliver, puzzled, looks from the cat Irena. She leans forward, smiling, trying to coax the kit to come to her. The kitten snarls and spits viciously at Oliver scoops it up in his hands. OLIVER (cont'd) Why, you little devil!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she rises to her feet) It's all right. It's just that cats don't seem to like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is only a kitten. It's very friendly. When I had it in the office, Alice ГўВЂВ” the girl who works in our department ГўВЂВ” it played with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling uncomfortably) Cats just don't like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver has stuffed the kitten back into its box and put t lid over it. He is obviously disappointed. Irena puts her hand on Oliver's arm. IRENA (cont'd) (Brightly) I know what we can do. You got it at a pet store, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. We could exchange it for some other pet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at him. He nods. IRENA (cont'd) I'll get my hat and coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to go back into the apartment for her coat and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is tranquil in Miss Plunkett's Pet Shoppe. Outside it is raining, a soft autumn rain. Miss Plunkett sits noddin Most of the birds and animals are sleeping. Above Miss Plunkett, in a circular stand, a brilliant macaw swings. looks very much like Miss Plunkett, and, like her, is peacefully nodding in sleep. A little bell tinkles, and there is the sound of the door opening and closing. Miss Plunkett sleeps right on. We see that Irena and Oliver ha entered the shop. Immediately there is a transformation. The birds begin to call back and forth to one another, their calls growing excited, shrill. The monkeys, awakene clamber excitedly in their cages, whimpering and chatteri madly. The puppies begin to bark, the cats to meow.  In a moment the sound has grown to sheer cacophony. The macaw, too, has awakened, and is screeching its head off. Miss Plunkett snaps out of her stolen rest and looks about her blinking curiously. Her lips form the words of amazement, "Landie, dearie me!" but there is so much noise now that nothing she says can be heard.  She looks up to see what may have startled the animals into such noisy activity; MED. SHOT of Irena and Oliver, as they stand, perplexed b all the commotion.  Oliver is closing an umbrella. Miss Plunkett comes into the scene.  She tries to yell to the animals to bo quiet.  The noise is too much for her.  Oli tries to explain to Miss Plunkett that he wants to exchan the kitten, which he holds in the box in his hands, for a canary, but he cannot make himself heard.  She only shake her head and tries to say something at which Oliver shake his head.  Irena touches Oliver's arm, indicating that it might bo better to go outside.  Oliver points outdoors to Miss Plunkett.  She nods and follows them out onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT.  The three emerge from the store, Miss Plunket closing the door behind her.  All three stand under the umbrella.  In the loud, shrieking voice she has been usin Miss Plunkett starts to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She realizes she doesn't have to talk so loudly now, and, with an embarrassed laugh, begins again in her natural vo MISS PLUNKETT (cont'd) Landie, dearie me!  I can't imagine what got into them... all that caterwauling.  The last time they did that was when an alley cat got in and ate up one of my nice rice finches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want is to exchange this kitten for a bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, of course. I have some lovely canaries. One little lemon-colored follow with top notes like Caruso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door cautiously and peeks in, turning back them with a pleased expression MISS PLUNKETT (cont'd) As peaceful as my dream of heaven! Shall we go back now and select just which little birdie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oliver) You go, please, Oliver.  Pick the one you like. It's so hot and stifling in there. I'd rather stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Irena the umbrella) Of course.  I'll only bo a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver and Miss Plunkett return inside the shop, Miss Plunkett talking all the while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Animals are ever so psychic. There are some people who just can't come in hero. My dear brother's wife, for instance; she's a very nice girl...I've nothing against her...but you should just see what happens when she puts her foot inside this place. The cats particularly. They seem to know. You can fool everybody, but landie, dearie me, you can't fool a cat. In some ways they seem to know who's not right ГўВЂВ” if you know what I mean.  (she has the bird in her hand and holds it up with pleasure) Here we are! Isn't he a ducky little angel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver takes the bird and holds it up for Irena to see. Irena, standing outside the window, looking in, nods her head eagerly. Oliver turns back to Miss Plunkett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT of Irena. The little bell tinkles over the door Oliver comes out with the bird in a small wooden cage. He comes over to Irena. She exchanges the umbrella for the b cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her the cage) What do you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena holds the cage up before her eyes, tenderly to the bird. She coos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, he is sweet! (turns and smiles up at Oliver) He will like me very much. You will see. I like to be liked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver takes her by the arm and smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ought to be easy. Really easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start away together up the street, under the umbrell smiling at one another, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. In the b.g. the ship plans on the wall can be seen. They are complete now as far back as the flying bri Obviously some time has elapsed. Oliver and Alice are sitting back to back, both of them d particularly exacting pieces of mathematical measuring. Oliver raises up to call out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice makes no motion. He turns to her more definitely, calling out again, louder this time: OLIVER (CONT'D) (cont'd) Let me borrow your slide rule, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Alice is in the midst of a difficult problem, and she goes on with it.  Oliver turns around to her, places one around her, and whispers in her ear after the fashion of Charles Boyer. OLIVER (CONT'D) (cont'd) Mademoiselle, you are so beautiful  - so charming. So gracious a lady will surely pass me her slide rule, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice succumbs.  She looks up at him and gives him the sl rule.  Then she gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) I have to wash the taste of that out of my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes over to the water cooler.  Oliver follows her, Alice looks up to see Jim Carver approaching. ALICE (cont'd) Look who's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver winks at her,  Jim reaches the two at the water cooler. Alice has a paper cup full of water in one hand. She takes out a coin with the other hand. ALICE (cont'd) Doc, I'll bet there's one thing you can't do..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating with belt on her dress) I'll bet you a dollar you can't hold a quarter on your forehead like this, pull out your belt, lower your head, and let the quarter fall bingo into your trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the quarter; with confidence) A mere matter of precision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He balances the quarter on his forehead, throwing his hea back to do so. He holds out the front of his trousers. Ol takes a box of paper clips from a near-by desk and emptie them into Carver's trousers. They all laugh. Carver laugh with them. At this moment the Commodore comes down from t mezzanine. There is instant silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to go out on my boat Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone ad libs enthusiastic acceptance except Oliver. Carver, forgetting the paper clips, joins in and moves a little more than he should; a deluge of clips falls aroun his ankles. The Commodore looks at him, then back to Oliver. COMMODORE (cont'd) Don't you want to go, Ollie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact is, sir, I've got an engagement for Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boat seems to have competition, Commodore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should meet the competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you met her, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw her one day with Ollie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Oliver) Ollie's always saying he'll take me to see her, but he never does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, Alice, I was going to take you around next Sunday, but since the Commodore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I withdraw my invitation to you two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take a rain check, Commodore, (looks at Oliver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to go) I'll expect the rest of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts toward the door.  Carver moves to get out of hi way.  There is a veritable deluge of clips.  The Commodor looks down at the clips and then gives Carver a long and searching glance. COMMODORE (cont'd) I always wondered what held you together, Carver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, Irena, and Oliver are walking Into the room.  It i obvious that Alice and Oliver have just arrived and been at the door by Irena.  She has her free arm linked throug Alice's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think, Alice, I shall like you very much.  We shall be good friends, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is a little embarrassed by Irena's warmth of manner She looks about the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ollie tells me you like to draw cats.  I tried to draw a cat once -- looked more like a mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cats are harder to draw than the human hand...a good cat portrait is almost impossible.  Look up there... (pointing to the mantel picture) Even Goya couldn't do it...not really well.  That's why I like It...because it's hard.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) Because it's hard? You're a glutton for punishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not just because it's hard.  In a way, I felt I had to draw them.  Didn't you draw boats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I spent half my study periods drawing boats. The Marblehead tomboy ГўВЂВ” that was me.. My poor mother wept every time I brought home a report card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I drew cats. The other children in my village had cats, and they could hug them and play with them. But cats don't like me. They won't let me cuddle or caress them.  So instead of playing with them, I drew them.  They're the one subject still too hard for me. You understand, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without waiting for an answer, she rises and picks up a s of drawings from nor desk.  She spreads them out before Alice. IRENA (CONT'D) (cont'd) Look,  Fashion drawings bore mo.  The only way I can do them is this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice picks up one of the drawings and looks at it, IRENA (CONT'D) (cont'd) Of course, when I got the gown the way I want it, I rub out the cat's face and sketch in a regular face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice nods and puts the drawing back with the others. Oli looking at Alice, is afraid that she has not been sufficiently Impressed. He feels called upon to defend Irena's work and to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's right clever. How about my mixing a cocktail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have them all mixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries off behind the screen.  Alice looks up at Oliver,  He is beaming with pride.  She smiles at him, holding up her finger, ring-joined, in a little gesture o silent approval.  The canary beings to sing.  Alice rises and goes over to the canary's cage. Oliver joins her besi the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what the kitten turned into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much easier for a working girl to keep. (as the bird hits an especially high note) Listen to her, will you? Little old Jenny Lind herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bird suddenly stops singing.  Alice and Oliver look a one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over scene) Was the bird singing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  It gave out with an aria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena comes toward them.  She holds a small tray upon whi is a martini whirler, three glasses, and a small plateful hors d'oeuvres.  She places the cocktail things upon a sm table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never sung before.  This is the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes up to the cage, trying to coax the bird into so with little cooing and whistling noises.  The bird mopes its perch as far away from her as the cage will allow. IRENA (cont'd) The naughty bird. For me he will never sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably a prima donna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning toward the coffee table, Irena speaks suddenly, a with a desire to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we have our martinis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver bends down, gets the glasses, and hands them aroun Just as they lift their glasses, the eerie scream of the panther sounds.  Oliver and Alice look up. IRENA (cont'd) It's the panther --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting his glass) Here's luck to all of us...May we always be in better voice than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSEUP of Alice. She is twirling the glass in her fingers thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The panther is pacing behind the bars of its cage. It is windy day, one of the last days of fall. A gust of wind b a shower of dead leaves across the screen in front of the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of the panther screen, glowing In bright firelight.  Over this shot comes the melody of "Berceuses Chat." CAMERA DRAWS BACK to Include CLOSE SHOT of Irena near the phonograph as she turns down the music so that it Is only background music. She is wearing an attractive hostess go She goes over to the sofa where Oliver is stretched out a sits beside him. Irena's fingers begin to stroke his brow regularly. She smiles down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better.  Those under-lit tables we work at...we had to use them all day today... they give a man a rotten headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Alice? Doesn't she mind them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so, but she never lets anything bother her.  She says the best cure for anything is swimming. (his voice begins to get sleepy) She only lives at that women's club because there's a pool there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena continues to caress his brow. His head sinks down i the pillows. He closes his eyes. An outside sound distrac Irena, and she looks up. CLOSE SHOT of the window from Irena's viewpoint.  It has begun to rain, and a blast of wind has spangled the windo with raindrops. CLOSE SHOT of Irena as she smiles contentedly and looks d at Oliver.  He has fallen asleep and is breathing easily. moves gently, and one hand extends over the edge of the s Irena lets herself slide from the sofa to the floor.  She nestles against the sofa, cuddles her cheek against the b of Oliver's outstretched hand, and rubs her face back and forth, almost like a cat that pets itself against its master's hand.  Her eyes look toward the dancing flames i the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT of the fire.  The flames have burned down.  There ar only glowing coals on the hearth.  The room is almost dar The music has stopped. The CAMERA MOVES from the fire to Irena, as she still sit the floor with her cheek against Oliver's hand, Oliver st slightly and opens his eyes.  Irena does not move.  Olive looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It  couldn't have been very entertaining for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was watching you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that was fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena makes a little purring murmur of assent.  There is pause then Oliver speaks softly. OLIVER (cont'd) Do you love me, Irena?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the little murmur of ascent. OLIVER (cont'd) I thought so. And you know that I love you, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the little, happy, thrilling murmur from the darkness.  Oliver puts his hand on her shoulder. OLIVER (cont'd) I've never kissed you. (pauses) You know, that's funny,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena withdraws gently from him and moves back a bit into the shadows away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When people in America know each other as well as we do ГўВЂВ” when they're in love ГўВЂВ” or oven think they're in love, they've usually kissed long ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena slips further away from him into the shadows.  He l toward her. OLIVER (cont'd) Well...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can see only the dim outline of her shoulders, the whi blur of her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly taut, anguished, as if the words were being pulled from her throat) I love you, Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up, alarmed by her intensity) For heaven's sake, Irena, what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without answering, Irena suddenly lays her cheek against knee and beings to sob. Perplexed, Oliver looks down at h and puts a hand on her head.  She turns her head but does look at him.  Her voice has a wild, strained quality, ech some strange agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lived in dread of this moment, Oliver.  I've not wanted to love you.  I kept myself away from people...I stayed alone...I never wanted this to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you just told me you loved me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver puts his hands under her elbows and tries to draw up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there's only one thing to do.  Come up here and be kissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (withdrawing from his hands) No. I can't, Oliver,  I've fled from the past, from things   you could never know or understand...evil things... evil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks out again, sobbing. He looks down at her, worr Her sobs lessen, and Oliver begins to speak very quietly, very calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena, you've told me something of the past...of King John, and the witches in the village, and the cat people who are descended from them.  Fairy tales, Irena, fairy tales you heard in childhood...nothing more than that.  They've nothing to do with you, really. You're Irena...you're here In America...you're so normal you're even in love with me...Oliver Reed...a good, plain Americano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to raise her again, to kiss her, but she eludes and cuddles down by his feet, pressing her cheek against knee.  She has stopped crying. OLIVER (cont'd) Yes, you're so normal that you're going to marry me, Irena, And those fairy tales of yours, you can tell them to our children... for them...hundreds of kittens to amuse them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena utters a little murmur of happiness and delight. Oliver bends over, and kisses her hair softly.. Over the sound of the rain and wind comes the coughing roar of lions in the park.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.
dialogues.text: The Belgrade, as seen through the plate glass window from outside.  It la snowing, the first light snow of the wint In the window on display are three calves' heads prepared Serbian fashion.  They have been skinned.  The eyes, considered a great delicacy by gourmets, are wide open an glisten like bullets.  The heads are crowned with chaplet artificial flowers. In the b.g. we see the wedding party. Seated around a table are Oliver, Irena, Alice, the Commodore, Jim Carver, and some of the other people we ha seen on the office sequences.  Irena is dressed in a ligh suit and wears a bridal bouquet on her shoulder.  She is laughing a natural, happy laugh to contrast with the late hysterical laugh.  The proprietor of the restaurant has j brought proudly to the table from the kitchen a large iro kettle from which the steam of hot wine is rising. The CAMERA TRUCKS THROUGH to the wedding party.  A trio o musicians, dressed in Balkan costume, is playing a Balkan love song.  Jim Carver, like everyone else in the party, been drinking, and is in a gay mood.  As the proprietor places the iron kettle on the table, Carver applauds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Ah!  Comitaji!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proprietor gives him a fierce look.  Irena laughs merrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh,   Mr. Carver,   you   should  not call  the   good man  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's Serbian.  I got it from my barber this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might insult him.  "Comitaji" means bandit...robber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless my soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commodore Judson, seated next to Alice, is watching Irena He turns to find Alice's eyes on his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver's bride seems a very nice girl...and very pretty too. Carver tells me she's a bit odd. He's a little worried about the marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Nonsense.  Irena's a grand gir1. She and Oliver are going to be very happy together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT of a woman who is seated at a little tabl the far side of the restaurant.  She is in evening dress, is dining alone.  The woman looks like a cat.  She has a round, tabby face and a pompadour which somehow suggests roundness of a cat's head.  The eyes, slanting, large, an very light in color, fringed with sweeping lashes, are completely feline.  She turns these great, luminous eyes the direction of the wedding party and stares at the festivities. MED. SHOT of the wedding party.  The Commodore rises, wit his glass in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody toasts Irena.  Oliver looks down at her, proud happy. CLOSEUP of the Cat Woman, as she looks straight at Irena. MED. SHOT of the wedding party.  As the Commodore is sitt down, he sees the Cat Woman. He turns to Jim Carver. COMMODORE (cont'd) Look at that woman.  Isn't she something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing up)  Looks like a cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to his food. MED. SHOT - the Cat Woman. Drawing-on her gloves, she ris and crosses the room. As she reaches the wedding party an directly opposite Irena, she stops and stares at Irena. MED. SHOT - the wedding party, holding her hand as she ta Irena is turned to Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Alice, for this lovely party.  I did not know there was a Serbian restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you want to know about this city, ask me.  I know all the unimportant details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena laughs, and turning around, looks up at the Cat Wom The smile fades from her face.  She stares at the woman w a kind of haunted fascination.  The Cat Woman takes a ste closer, never removing her eyes from Irena.  She smiles a speaks.  (Note:  Irena's voice is to be dubbed in on the sound track when the Cat Woman speaks.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moja sestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena blanches and shrinks, back into her chair.  She mak the sign of the Cross. The Cat Woman smiles and repeats t words.  (Note:  Scene without sign of Cross to be made fo England.) CAT WOMAN (cont'd) Moja sostra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and walks out back on a festive basis. Alice tries to put the party

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WO SHOT - Oliver and Irena.  Irena is looking white and shaken.  Oliver takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did that woman say to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena looks up at him with frightened eyes, OLIVER (cont'd) What did she say, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, seriously) If this were any night but-my wedding night...If you were any man but my husband...I would not tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  It can't be that serious...just one single word --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very seriously) She greeted me...she called me "sister." (seizing his hands, looking up at him) You saw her, Oliver.  You saw what she looked like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, the cat people ... she's one of the cat people.  She looks like a cat, and so she must be one of the cat people...one of King John's pets.  (tweaks her chin playfully) Irena, you crazy kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena looks at him from her throat sobs of hysterical laughter break OLIVER (cont'd) Look...you're laughing.  You can see how funny it is yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is true.  Irena is laughing with him, but hers is forced, flat laughter of near hysteria. The CAMERA MOVES IN so that we see that it is hysteria, whereas Oliver, seated beside her, feels sure it Is norma laughter joined with his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab draws up before Irena's apartment house.  In it are Oliver, Irena, the Commodore, and Carver.  It is still snowing lightly.  Carver is the first out, extricating himself from the jump seat.  He helps Irena out, and Oliv follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a joke about weddings. Why would my wedding be a dollar and cents wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Irena.  She does not say anything.  He looks around at the rest.  No one says anything.  Then the Commodore pokes his head out of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I haven't d dollar, and my girl hasn't any sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one laughs.  It hasn't bean a funny joke.  Then Irena, begins to laugh.  She laughs hysterically.  Oliver locks her worried.  Carver is very pleased, because he thinks h has been funny.  The Commodore reaches out from the cab a taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along, Carver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver climbs into the cab, and it drives off. TWO SHOT of Irena and Oliver on the sidewalk.  The soft s falls on their shoulders.  For the first time they are al together, and Irena's problems have to be discussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena  is struggling to put a hard request into reasonabl words.  She forces herself to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to beg --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks off, unable to speak.  They stand there a mome Oliver is looking at her.  He wants to help her; he wants know the way of her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (encouragingly; softly) Mrs. Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena stops and puts her hands tenderly against his chest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to hear that...nice. I want to be Mrs.. Reed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are, Irena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I want to be Mrs. Reed really. I want to be everything that name means to me ГўВЂВ” (with tears coming to her eyes) -- and I can't -- I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no sense in what you're saying, darling. You're excited. That woman in the restaurant upset you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brought back the old fears. If I could have some time to -- (seizing his hands) Oliver, be kind -- be patient - let me have time - time to get over this feeling there's something evil in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver looks at her quietly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, you can have all the time there is In the world, If you want it, and all the patience and the kindness there's in me. You didn't have to ask for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena draws his hand to her lips and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a little  time...only a  little time,  Oliver.  I don't want more than that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn toward the house,   and  as   they begin to wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena  is   crossing the room toward the door.    The  ro is lighted only by the glow from the street lamps outside She is in a negligee. Outside, through the window, the sn can be  soon falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver, still wearing street clothes, stands  at  the doo Irena's bedroom. He  taps  lightly on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Good night, Irena,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He  stands waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena presses herself against the door.    Her hand goes to  the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver  stands waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena sinks down to her knees beside the door and crouche there, lonely and desirous.  She moves slightly. Her hand goes up toward the doorknob.  There is no doubt that her intention is to open the door.  From the park comes the t eerie scream of the panther.  Irena listens, trembles, an takes her hand from the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) Good night, Oliver..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the other side of the door) Good night, Irena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The keeper of the cat cages is sweeping out the blank panther's cage with a long-handled broom.  He sings to himself in a nasal New England voice.  Irena comes and st at the guard rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was not any person hurt, Except the Reverend Parson Burt...  (sliding the broom handle far into the cage) He wasn't killed by cannon ball, As judged by jurors one and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The panther steps haughtily over the broom handle, and co up to the bars. KEEPER (cont'd) But being in a sickly state, He frightened fell and met his fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leopard, maneuvering for a better view of Irena, gets in the way of the broom.  The old keeper stops his work a his song, turning to see what has attracted the leopard's attention.  On seeing Irena, he tips his peaked cap and smiles,. KEEPER (cont'd) Ain't seen you here for some time, ma1am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been married.  I've been married almost a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Withdrawing his broom, the old keeper uses it as a crutch support himself.  He jerks one thumb in the direction of leopard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I tell this misbegotten devil...nobody comes to see him when they're happy.  The monkey house and the aviary draw the happy customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena leans over the guard rail.  The leopard's hackles r and he tenses his front paws to unsheathe the talons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiringly) But he's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He ain't beautiful.  He's an evil creature, ma'am.  You read your Bible.  In Revelations -- when the Book is talking about the worst beast of them all -- it says, "And the beast which I saw was like unto a leopard."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating softly) Like unto a leopard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am, like a leopard... but not a leopard.  I guess that fits this fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it fits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses a moment, then leaves the guard rail to contin on her way down the promenade.  The old keeper calls afte her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best wishes for your marriage, ma' am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and waves to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The panther screen is glowing in the bright sunlight streaming through the window.  The sun throws a shadow on the screen just over the panther.  It is the enlarged sha of tbe bird cage, with the canary hopping about inside th bars. CAMERA DRAWS BACK to show Irena at her desk.  She has jus finished working on a sketch.  Now she gets up, stretchin and turning. Her eyes fall on the bird in its cage, and s crosses over to it, the CAMERA MOVING with her.  The bird huddles on its perch, frightened, Irena tries to encourag to sing.  She whistles a few notes.  Still no response. opens the small door of the cage, and puts her hand insid take hold of the canary.  The bird flutters wildly.  Befo she can get hold of it, it falls to the cage floor and li there. Irena picks it up tenderly and holds it in her han The bird is dead.  Irena is serious and concerned as she the bird down on a table, opens a drawer, and takes out a empty bonbon box.  Very carefully she places the dead bir the box, and ties it up with a bit of ribbon.  She puts o her hat and coat, gets a trowel chat Is on. The window lo by one of the window boxes, and leaves the room with the trowel and the box under her handbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena walks along the park path. The CAMERA is MOVING wit her. Her eyes are searching for a likely spot of earth to bury the dead bird. Under a bush she spies a bit of soft earth. She stops, and takes a step toward It. A whistled attracts her attention, and she looks up. A policeman has rounded a corner of the path, and is comi toward her amiably swinging his nightstick, as he whistle "Who?"  Irena swiftly pushes the purse back on her arm an continues walking along the path, passing the policeman, who goes right on whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena comes up the walk.  The panther is pacing back and forth behind the bars.  It stops pacing as she passes the cage.  She, too, stops, and looks at the beast. Suddenly, if under the compulsion of some thought or desire outside herself, she hurriedly takes the box, tears off the lid, throws the dead body of the canary into the cage. CLOSE SHOT of the panther, as daintily, with little paw p it begins to play with the dead bird, shuffling the tiny yellow body across the dusty floor of the cage, CLOSE SHOT of Irena watching the animal.  She shudders, almost as if recovering herself, and turning, walks quick away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena is standing looking out the window.  Oliver is open the little cabinet which they use for a bar.  He half tur and calls over his shoulder to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some sherry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena doesn't answer.  Oliver fills two glasses with sher and brings them over to her.  He offers her one. OLIVER (CONT'D) (cont'd) Here. If you're determined to mourn that bird...we'11 have a regular wake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just because the bird died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver puts a glass Into her hands and stands beside her. takes a little sip of the wine and stares into the glass, thoughtfully. IRENA (cont'd) It's me.  I envy every woman I see on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't match your little finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I envy them.  They are happy. They make their husbands happy. They lead normal, happy lives. They're free... (a pause) The bird...do you know what happened to the bird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It died of fright when I tried to take it In my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  The bird was afraid of you -- that's nothing.  I had a rabbit once that hated me; yet I grew up to be quite a nice fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Oliver, when I went past the panther's cage I had to open the box; I had to throw the bird to him, (a pause; then more intensely) Do you understand?...I had to. I had to do it!  That's what frightens me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver looks at her for a moment then, speaks quietly, no longer mocking her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to kid you out of it. Maybe that's wrong. I've tried...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) No one could have been more gentle or more patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried to make you realize all these stories that worry you are so much nonsense. Now I see it's not the stories... it's the fact that you believe them. We've got to have help, Irena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena half turns. The statuette of King John is on the ta before her. She lets one hand rest for a minute on the ba of the figure.  Oliver follows the direction of her gaze he shakes his head. OLIVER (cont'd) Not that sort of help.  There's something wrong, and we have to face it in an intelligent way. We don't need a King John with fire and sword.  We need someone who can root out the reason for your belief and cure it. That's what we need ГўВЂВ” a psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena turns toward him, her face eager and hopeful,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Find one for me, Oliver.  The best one...the very best one I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Irena. She is in a dark room. Coming diagon across is a square shaft of light which falls softly on Irena's face, framing the closed eyes, the nose, and the mouth, leaving everything else in undisturbed darkness. F the darkness comes a male voice, a very persuasive, insis voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the cats...the cats...you were saying the cats....the cats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes still closed as she speaks) They torment me. I wake in the night, I fool their warmth and their strength in me...in me. I walk in the day, and the tread of their foot whispers in my brain.  I have no peace...for they are in me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, and a little grimace of pain goes over her features. From her closed eyes two tears course slowly do her cheeks.  From the darkness the voice continues to urg her on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In me... in me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no response. The man gets up, so that we see him silhouette.  He crosses the room and draws the curtains, letting in the brilliant sunlight.  Irena lies with eyes closed, breathing with the shallow, regular breath of sle undisturbed by the harsh light. TWO SHOT of Irena and Dr. Louis Judd.  He stands for a mo watching her.  Judd is a harshly ugly man of early middle ago.  There is an arrogance in his bearing which makes so women see him as the suave, continental man, perfectly su of his success with any woman.  His consulting room is cl antiseptic, and sparsely furnished with a couch, a chair, a gooseneck lamp on a stand.  Irena is lying on the couch Judd, standing beside her, makes a few notations on a pad Then he lightly pats her cheek to wake her.  She comes fr sleep very quietly. JUDD (cont'd) You are very tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling uncertainly)  No...not very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Judd pours her n drink from a carafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hypnosis always tires me. And some of my patients, too, find it exhausting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the glass he gives her) It's only that I remember nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But It 1s my duty to remember, (patting the notebook in his hand) I have it all here.  Most Interesting.  You told me of your village, and the people, and their strange beliefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxiously)  Is that all I told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me tales of blood, violence...mangled bodies in dark forests...men torn to death by woman half witch, half panther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so ashamed.  It must seem so childish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the cat woman of your village...you told me of them, too...woman who In jealousy or anger, or out of their own corrupt passions, could change into great cats, like panthers. And if one of those woman were to fall in love...and if her lover were to kiss her...take her into his embrace, she would be driven by her own evil to kill him. JUDD (cont'd) (pausing, coming closer to her) That's what you believe and what you fear, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena nods her head but does not raise her eyes. JUDD (cont'd) Frankly, there is no need to be ashamed.  This is only what we call a psychological block...a thing which stands between you and what you really desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena looks at him.  He looks at his watch, crosses to th desk and puts away his notebook with an air of finality. JUDD (cont'd) Those things are very simple to psychiatrists.  You told me of your childhood.  Perhaps we'll find this trouble stems from some early experience. You said you didn't know your father...that he had died in some mysterious accident in the forest before your birth...and because of that the children teased you and called your mother a witch...a cat woman. These childhood tragedies are inclined to corrode the soul, to leave a canker in the mind, but we will try to repair the damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena rises and gives Dr. Judd her hand.  He places an ar around her shoulders with familiar ease, as he leads her the door. JUDD (cont'd) You are not to worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall I tell my husband? Naturally, he is anxious to have some word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with heavy gallantry; as he assists her with her coat) What does one tell a husband? One tells him nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time they have reached the door to the outer offi - the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Judd and Irena enter and cross to the door which lead the hall. He opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday, at eleven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena nods and leaves. Dr. Judd turns to another of his patients in the waiting room. She is a beautiful, neuroti looking woman, swathed in furs and adorned with loops of pearls. Judd bows from the waist to kiss her hand. JUDD (cont'd) My dear lady.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Irena running lightly up the stairs, hummin a little snatch of song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of Irena as she reaches the top of the stairs goes down the hallway to her door, still humming the song Joyously she swings open the door of the apartment* CLOSEUP of Irena as she sees something inside, REVERSE SHOT. Through the door can be seen Oliver and Ali seated together on the sofa. Oliver-is just bending over light Alice's cigarette. They turn and look as Irena ente and closes the door. Irena, Alice and Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she crosses to Alice) Alice, it's so nice to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, darling.    How did you make  out with Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Louis ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr.  Judd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantly Irena's mood changes.    She  looks at Alice, puzzled and a little hurt  to think that Oliver has spoke of her visit to the psychiatrist.    Oliver catches Irena look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Alice knows, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not catching the vibrations in the air) Of course.  Didn't I suggest Dr.  Judd?    I met him on the Commodore's boat.    The way he goes around kissing hands makes me want to spit cotton, but I guess he knows all there is to know about psychiatry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is looking very embarrassed.    Irena is both star and angry now.    Alice looks at both of them and catches ALICE (cont'd) Uh-oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Irena) I told Alice; I knew she'd know some good doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why that was necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her manner is very cold.  She gives them both a long look and walks away to stand by the window, gazing out, with h back toward them. Alice looks guiltily at Oliver, shrugs her shoulders, and picks up her hat and coat from a near- chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  I seem to have put my big foot in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets Oliver help her on with her coat, and, with her still in her hand, she goes over to the door. Pausing, sh calls out to Irena. ALICE (cont'd) Sorry, Irena.  I'm sure neither I nor Oliver had any notion of offending you.  I'm dreadfully sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-turning, coldly)  Good-bye, Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With another-guilty look at Oliver, Alice closes the door behind her. The moment the door clicks shut, Irena turns face Oliver.  She is furious, hurt, offended. Oliver trie make nice with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, really, there's no reason....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Oliver, how can you discuss such things...such intimate things about me? How much did you tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly)  You can tell Alice anything. She's such a good egg, she can understand anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some things a woman doesn't want other women to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses the room, goes into the bedroom, and closes t door firmly behind her.  Oliver is honestly perplexed. He looks after her ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena is unable to sleep.  A bright moon drives a shaft o misty light through the window and across her bed. She tu restlessly, gets up, and goes to the window for a moment look out.  From the park comes the sound of the lions and eerie, piercing shriek that she knows is the leopard's cr She trembles, perhaps with cold, perhaps with some emotio that she cannot understand.  She comes to a decision, thr a fur coat over her nightdress, outs on a pair of galoshe over her bedroom slippers, and lets herself out of the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena hesitates as she tiptoes across the studio room of apartment.  The moonlight Is pouring in through the windo throwing the familiar objects of the room Into mysterious half-shadows.  She goes quietly over to the other door, o it quietly, and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is sound asleep In his bed.  He sleeps quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena closes the door to Oliver's bedroom softly, and tip to the main door, snapping the night latch back, and quie letting herself out.

dialogues.speaker: X
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT.  Oliver comes out of the shadows of the hallway joins Irena on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I woke up.  You were gone, What's wrong, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause, as she looks at him)  I couldn't sleep.  I went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue up the stairs together, the CAMERA HOLDING them.  As they reach a landing, Oliver stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just walked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a brief pause.  Oliver reaches out and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about this afternoon. I just didn't think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should never quarrel, Oliver. I need you so much. You must help me, Oliver. (pauses) Never let me feel jealousy or anger. Whatever it is that is In me is held in...is kept harmless...when I am happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd turn handsprings, darling... I'd dance In the streets...to make you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles down at her.  Then, taking her little face in h hands, he pinches her cheeks together so that her mouth puckers to an enforced smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena stands at the guard rail, watching the old keeper unlock the cage door and throw in the big, bloody chunks meat. He is singing again his monotonous, nasal song, but even his singing cannot drown out the noisy feeding of th panther as it gnaws and tears at the meat. When he has th in the last chunk, he slams shut the cage door and moves It is a gusty, blowy day of hard, inconstant winds.  Iren notices that he has left the key in the look of the cage. INSERT THE KEY in the panther cage lock. BACK TO SCENE.  Irena pushes aside the little gate, gets key, stands with it for a moment in her hands, and then r after the keeper. She holds it out toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot your key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the key) Ah, I'm always forgettin' it, 'Tain't no worry in It. Nobody'd steal one of them creatures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves on, muttering his monotonous song to himself. Ir returns to the little gate. Dr. Judd is now standing wher she had formerly stood. He is smiling at her.  She lets herself out of the gate and stands beside him. H leans on his cane with a great air of nonchalant ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You resist temptation admirably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temptation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For many reasons. There is, in some cases, a psychic need to loose evil upon the world. And we all of us carry within us a desire for death. You fear the panther; yet you are drawn to him again and again. Could you not turn to him as an instrument of death? (a pause) You didn't come back to see me Friday.    I've had to come to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) How did you know where to find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)  You told me many things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena looks away. Irena and Dr. Judd as SHOT from within the panther's cage The black panther moves from time to time in the foregrou sometimes blotting one and then the other character from view. Irena and Judd are seen through the bars of the cag JUDD (cont'd) Why didn't you come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel that you can help me. You are very wise. You know a great deal. Yet when you speak of the soul, you mean the mind...and it is not my mind that is troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a clever girl! All the psychologists, all the theologians have tried for centuries to find that subtle shade of difference between mind and soul...and you have found it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically, turning away) It does seem presumptuous of me, doesn't it? Good-bye, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts off.  The CAMERA STAYS with her, as we hear o. Judd's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can cut one thread of fear for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena turns back to him questioningly, and he smiles at h as he joins her on the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother. Do you remember her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. My mother was a peasant. She was lovely...quiet and strong...a big woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor takes one of her hands and holds it up before

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this aristocratic little hand...is this a peasant hand? The little bones of this wrist...are they peasant bones? (drops her hand and looks at her) The mystery of your father is very simple. Perhaps a young aristocrat from Belgrade... maybe an artist on a sketching trip. And your mother..fresh and attractive, as peasant girls are when they are young. (making a little gesture with his cane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite clear ГўВЂВ” a hasty marriage...a brief pastor then he disappears. JUDD (cont'd) No wonder your mother never spoke of him...that the village people drew aside from her. As for the children who teased you...who would explain his absence to them? Naturally, they could only go by old wives' tales of cat women and violence,  (pauses, looking closely at Irena) I'm right, am I not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irena pauses thoughtfully for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) But what of my mother's death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her death? You didn't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still quietly) I held her hand when she died. That hand...even as I held it... turned to the black paw of a panther.  I felt the coarse hair, the sharp talons, the pads...I felt them... I saw her lying, black... I saw that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses and looks at Judd, who is frowning at her; she speaks, almost with a note of triumph, IRENA (cont'd) What little pastoral, Doctor... do you have to explain that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidently)  You were a child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thirteen when my mother died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did she die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was an epidemic in the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were sick, feverish, delirious, when your mother died?
